dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen from above: JESUS, the son of Mary, 28 years-old, es on a scrubby hillock under an olive tree. The mid-morning sun shines on his clean-shaven face. He is dreaming:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The pain starts just above the neck. It feels as if an old man has snuck up and grabbed me from behind. His fingers slip underneath the skin and work, claw, their way up the back of my neck. Then the real pain begins. Each finger digs into the soft matter behind my brain, and then strain across the top of my head toward my eyes. Just before they reach the eyes, they dig down... Jesus wakens. He looks around, holding his head.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) I remembered I had to make a cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus shapes a long piece of timber with an adze. His patched tunic rests on the workbench. The white plaster-and-brick walls are hung with the tools of Jesus’ trade: saws, hammers, rasps and measuring squares. Two small windows let in light and breeze from the village. His face is etched by lines caused by thinking too much. Brain fever. A nail-studded belt hangs from a hook above his head. The belt is speckled with dried blood.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 4c first I fasted for three months. Then I whipped myself before sleeping. At first it worked, then the headaches returned. Jesus wipes wood shavings from his sweaty chest. He hears a NOISE from outside. Frightened, he looks toward t jOor: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Who is it? Who are you? Why are you following me? JUDAS, 30, blacksmith, bursts into the room. The door RATTLES on its wood hinges. Jesus goes back to work. Judas' face is ablaze with wild red hair, beard and moustache. His bulging forearms are dirtied by grease, burnt by fire. He belongs to the Sicarri ("assassins") the terrorist wing of,the Zealots, a radical Jewish po- litical organization. His presence is frightening.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: I thought I'd find you here. Aren't you ashamed? The carpenters from Cana and Capernaum refuse to make a cross for a Zealot, but you get up and throw yourself into it like a madman. Where's your pride? Jesus, silent, backs away.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (continuing) What if the Messiah were to come now and find you doing this? Jesus returns to his adze. He says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: . JESUS
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, Judas. I mst work.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Aren't you ashamed?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (softly) No.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: You've seen them hanging there for days, skin falling off their bodies. Crying night after night. Our prophets. Because of the Romans and men like you. A migrain moves across Jesus' face. He winces:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No, I don't have any pride. I don't go to Synagogue. I disobey the commandments. I work on the Sabbath. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: And who will pay for your sins?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm struggling. Judas, disgusted, calls to the crowd outside.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Come here! Look at the traitor! Look at the cross-maker. The crowd jeers. Jesus resumes his task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CENTURION pushes his way through the crowds gathered outside the white-washed buildings. He is sickened by the foul-smelling Jewry. Jesus stands outside his workshop hewing a cyprus cross. A semi-circle of spiteful Israelites surrounds hin, The Centurion approaches:

dialogues.speaker: CENTURION
dialogues.text: You ready? (as Jesus nods) Com’ on. Jesus takes the nail-studded belt from its hook and buckles it around his waist. The Centurion helps Jesus heft the cross-beam to his shoulders. The Centurion leads Jesus through a gauntlet the crowd has formes from the village to a rocky hill outside Nazareth. Ahead, six Roman soldiers lead the protesting ZEALOT. Two mounted soldiers flank the group. The Zealot, crazed by fear, possessed by God, calls out to anyone who will listen:

dialogues.speaker: ZEALOT
dialogues.text: Stand up Israelites! Now's the time of Judgement! Yahweh is counting everyone! Stand, be counted! The Zealot’s hands are tied behind him. His clothes are torn and bloody, his long hair and grey beard matted with blood and sweat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judas insinuates his way into a group of townspeople. Fearful of the Romans, he speaks wder his breath:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: How long are we going take this? Can we let the Romans kill anyone who opens his mouth? When are we going be men? When will we. be Jews? No one pays attention to Judas. Seeing this, he with- draws . The villagers heap abuse on Jesus. PETER and JAMES are in the crowd. MARY, 56, mother of Jesus, pushes her way through the crowd. She stands in front of Jesus, trying to hold back the crowd with her arms. She calls out:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (MOTHER OF JESUS)
dialogues.text: Forgive my son! He's crazy! He doesn't know what he's doing. He has problems. Ever since he was a baby. He's not well in the head. The crowd hoots her into silence. Jesus, turning his eyes from her, trudges forward. The CENTURION follows close behind. As they near the crucifixion site, another woman, MARY MAGDALENE, 25, approaches Jesus. She wears brightly colored clothes; her lips and cheeks are painted like a prostitute. The villagers revile her as she passes. She walks alongside Jesus, staring him in the face. The color flows from Jesus’ face: his resolve nearly melts with it.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Magdalene. Who told you to ceue?

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: You thought you could forget re. You never will. Jesus’ mind goes back to a day the previous year. Cut To:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: A wedding feast in the lake village of Magdala. A long table is spread with fresh fruit, cheeses, bread and wine (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY MAGDALENE'S FATHER proposes a toast:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Join me. A toast to the engagement of my first daughter, Mary, and Jesus of Nazareth. The celebrants raise their cups in a toast. Mary, Jesus' mother, beams. Away from the others, Jesus and Mary Magdalene speak.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I'll return. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: I don't wnderstand.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I can't marry. God won't let me. He's pursuing me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: That's not God, it’s the devil. (holds his head) Jesus, you need a woman.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I must be alone. He comes at night into my head. God's angry with me. He pushes her away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Are you serious? What about me? What will become of me? No one will have me. Jesus turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magdalene spits in Jesus' face:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Cross~-maker! Jesus lowers his face. The Zealot's voice rings out: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ZEALOT .
dialogues.text: Children, have faith in the God of Israel! Don't be afraid. Rome is in smoke. Remember the Maccabees, remember how they threw out the Greeks! In the same way we'll throw out the Romans! There is only one God of Hosts! The Zealot has reached the crucifixion site: a rocky, flint covered mound. The soldiers wait for the cross. Children throw pebbles at Jesus as he approaches the Zealot. The Roman guards brace themselves for violence. Jesus sets the cross down beside the Zealot. The guards wrestle the Zealot to the ground. Mary, unable to contain herself, bursts through the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (MOTHER OF JESUS)
dialogues.text: Jesus! My son! Get away from here! The guards move toward her. Peter and ANOTHER MAN help the women take her away before the Romans can arrest her. Judas, sickened by this spectacle, walks away. The guards place the Zealot on the cross and tie his arms Jesus, moving the weges, readies the hole for the cross. The Magdalene throws herself at the Zealot's feet:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Be brave! One of the calvarymen drives her back with his horse. There will be no revolt today. The guards prepare to drive the nails into the Zealot's hands. A hush comes over the crowd. The spike is placed in the Zealot's palm. The hammer raised. Metal hits metal: the spike pierces the upraised hand. The Zealot's scream (almost ecstatic) is echoed by the cr Blood spatters; a drop falls on Jesus' lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, without staff or sandals, walks quickly across a grassy plain northeast of Nazareth. Although mich of the lake district" of Galilee is rocky and barren today, it was not so in Jesus' time. Then it was a fertile and pleasant valley, the treasure of the Mid-East. It was jater denuded -by the Turks. Behind Jesus, Nazareth stirs to life. Jesus leans his body into the wind as he reaches the cres of a low ridge:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If I take the goat's path south to bypass Magdala and Tiberias. Traders from East and West go out of gheir way to drink and whore and... Jesus watches a small caravan headed down the hills towar the sea. He shakes these thoughts from his mind.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is the happiest moment of my life. I've always felt something was after me. IT must be as stupid as everyone says. God only wanted me to join him in the desert. He waits in a well at the Monastery. Jesus skips for joy as he walks:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why would he want somone as stunid as me? Thank you! He sings a psalm as he goes:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: “The Lord reigns, let the earth be glad' let the distant shores rejoice. Rise up, O Judge of earth; pay back the proud what they deserve. How long will the wicked, 0 Lord, how, long will the wicked be jubilant?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus walks a hundred yards off the coast of the Sea of Gennesaret (today called Galilee). In the water a group of men pull in their nets after a morning of fishing. The are ZEBEDEE, James and John, PHILIP, a shepherd, stands w then, By American standards, the Sea of Gennesaret is quite sma 13 miles long and 8 miles wide. From any point, the oppo- site shore is visible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: To this day its sweet, clear water is naturally stocked with fish. Because it's located in a pocket in the hills, Gennesaret remains subject to sudden violent storms. On shore, Judas talks with Peter. Zebedee, fiftiesh, is the father of James and John. Peter spots Jesus and calls out:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look who's here. Hey, Cross-maker! Jesus glances at them and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) You better keep walking. Don't stop here.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: Don't bother him. We're all part of the same plan. The fish says, 'God, don't let me get caught,' The fisherman says, 'God, give me fish.' Back to work. (to Judas) Hey, Red! You mind your own business, too. Philip walks over to Peter and Judas and says to Zebedee:

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Be careful, Zebedee. He's from the Idumea. Lions still live out there. Don't pick a fight with him. (to Judas) What's happening in the plain?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Everything's fine, Philip. The Lord's merciful. In Nazareth, He crucifies prophets. Here, He sends enough rain. to ruin a year's crops in one night. In Jerusalem, the Romans squat in the temple.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: Shut up. Whatever God does is right.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: It is for you. You hire fifty fishermen like slaves and pay them minimum. Then you give to the temple and get God's blessing.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: Hey, you got the mark of Cain on you. Now get out! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judas walks off, calling back to Zebedee:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to be in your boat when the. Messiah comes. Philip catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Wait. I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Why now? Were you afraid a few minutes ago? The King of the Jews is on his way. Decide what side you are on.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Help me. I am afraid. But, I can't stand it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (moves close to him) Philip, can you kill?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: A man?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: What do you think? Sheep?

dialogues.speaker: . PHILIP
dialogues.text: I killed a bull once, but never a man.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: A man's easier,

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (hushed) Are you one of them -- the Zealots?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid. We're fighting for freedom. The day will come when you ¢an join us, Do you have a knife?

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Carry it all the time. These are hard times. Judas opens his shirt revealing a double-edged dagger. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (continuing) . Yesterday the brotherhood condemned the traitor. The lot fell to me.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: The cross-maker?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (nods) Keep your mouth shut. Think about what I've said. The day will come when we will need you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: How will I know? Judas turns. to leave:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Don't be in a hurry. You're not one of the brothers yet. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus passes two PEASANT GIRLS reaping in an open field. Their partially open dresses reveal their sweaty breasts. As Jesus averts his eyes, one of the girls calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PEASANT GIRL
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND PEASANT GIRL
dialogues.text: (gesturing) There's water and bread in the house. (as Jesus declines) We keep a loaf for travelers. We call it the grasshopper's bread. The First Girl points to a distant village:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PEASANT GIRL
dialogues.text: But if you want love, go to Magdala. Both Girls giggle. Their sexuality frightens Jesus:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No, I must keep going. Jesus walks quickly away. The Girls turn to each other and laugh again.  10 11 11.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: walks along the seashore. Hearing FOOTSTEPS, he stops abruptly. Turns and looks:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Who's that? Who's following me? Seeing nothing. Jesus starts again. The FOOTSTEPS return -- LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is that you? He clutches his head, collapses to his knees in pain:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Magdalene! Magdalene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus walks through the narrow streets of Magdala a fish- market village on the Sea of Gennesaret, which also serve as a rest spot for caravaps and traders en route from the Indias to Tyre and Sidon. The streets are crowded with camels, donkeys and traders of all descriptions: Mongols on horseback, Afghans laden with rugs and blankets, Nubian slaves following their Greek and Roman masters. Jesus pushes his way through a crowd as he reaches the home of Mary Magdalene. A row of camels, horses and donkeys stand outside. Jesus enters. As Jesus enters, A NAZARENE calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: NAZARENE
dialogues.text: Ah, Carpenter, you've come to worship? The man laughs and moves on. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A camel sleeps by the well in the center of the courtyard Jesus latches the door behind him. A dozen traders and merchants are seated on benches aroun the courtyard; each waits his turn with the Magdalene. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They have come from the four corners of the earth. Side by side sit a Bedouin in a long white jellab, a young Indian nobleman with gold bands around his ankles, a fat green-turbaned TURK. The hot sun beats down on them all. Each sweats, looks impatiently from side to side, engages in small talk. How much are slaves selling for in Alexandria and Damascus? What is the trading price of cinnamon and pepper? A short Bedouin emerges from Magdalene's house. He passes through the courtyard without glancing to either side. The next in line, an old Jew, enters Magdelene's door. Th Turk calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: TURK
dialogues.text: Hurry up, old man. Don't take all day! The others join in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: is waning. Three merchants wait with Jesus. An old woman passes through selling bread, dates and wine. An Egyptian emerges from the Magdalene's house. Another man gets up. Jesus defers to him.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Jesus sits alone. The last customer closes the courtyard or. Jesus stands, enters Magdalene's house. curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus steps into the dark, amber-lit room. Mary, lies naked on a stack of blankets, covered with the sweat of all nations. Facing the wall, she calls out in a hoarse voice:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Is there anyone else? Jesus stops in the middle of the room, wable to go further. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mary turns and recognizes Jesus. She instinctively pulls the blanket over her nakedness.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: . JESUS
dialogues.text: I want you to forgive me. The Magdalene doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I've done a lot of wrong things. I'm going to the desert to be cleansed. The worst things I've done are to you. Forgive me,

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Ah, now I get it. You sit out there all day with the 'customers'. Then you come in here with your head down. La-te-ta. It ain't that easy. I ain't gonna forgive you just ‘cause you wanna be forgiven,

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (falls to his knees) It's my fault, but I'll pay the debt.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: You bleat like an animal. Lift your head up and face the truth. You want the same as the others. But you can't admit it, so you blame me. I pity you, Jesus. 1 detest you. Jesus, his head bowed low, starts to weep:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: You're full of the devil. Please, can’t you see that? Tears fall from Jesus' cheeks. Magdalene sits up, puts her arm on his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? A woman is like a wounded doe. All she can do is lick her wounds. That is her only joy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (looks at her) Don't you remember when we were children? Mary's eyes are also wet:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember. I pity you. I detest you. Every time I see you wy heart breaks. (starts to get up) Look the other way. I'm naked. Mary stands and puts a dress on. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Mary takes a casserole from the fire, pours it into a bow and hands it to Jesus with a barley roll. Jesus, starved, bites into the bread:

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Is that the way you eat? Without saying grace? Don't you think you oughta thank God for giving you bread, beans and whores? The bread sticks in Jesus' throat:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Why do you hate me? Why do you tease me? Let bygones be bygones. Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Stop whining. Forgiveness isn't given, it's taken. Jesus eats. Mary looks at him tenderly. She touches his ace.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember when we were children. When you were three and I was one. (Jesus does not respond) I remember when we laid under the tree together. There were three steps leading to your house. I'd watch you trying to climb. I wanted to help you but... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Magdalene is coming on to him. He is her one, her only, h lifetime love. No matter what he does, she eB hever stop” loving him. Jesus is afraid; he knows her power -- and his weakness.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Stop! He stands and walks over to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: I never felt so much tenderness toward anyone as felt for you then...

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: . (his head in his hands) Adoriai! God, help me! (to Magdalene) I'm thinking about God. I must leave... His voice is strangled, heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Please stay. That is, if you will condescend to share a prostitute's shabby room. “" (Jesus doesn't respond) It's cold. Sleep by the fire. Jesus walks to the door:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I can't stay.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: ‘Don't worry. I won't tempt you. I won't touch your precious virginity.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Jesus leaves. The door rattles against the jamb. A moment after he exits, Mary Magdalene sinks her head into the blankets, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus walks hurriedly toward a walled desert commme. The landscape is now barren, and wild. In the distance, sheer cliffs ascend from a sandy plain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In Christian times, these communes were called monasterie but these pre-Christian gutposts lacked the doctrinal sim and ascetic commitment of the later Catholic monasteries. They were simply groups of religious men living together meditate, do good works and preserve the Torah and other religious documents. Jesus knocks on the main door. He waits anxiously as the ABBOT? opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Thank God. I thought I’d never make it. Please let me in. I'm safe now. The Abbot, taken back, lets Jesus in. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: -- Jesus, now bearded, copies scrolls with other acolytes -- Jesus works the commune garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus: sleeps on a woven mat. He hears a HISSING SOUND. His eyes open, he sits up. A snake emerges from a hole in the wall and slithers acro the earthen floor. Another snake follows it. The snakes coil around each other and copulate. Jesus sits up, his back to the wall, watching:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why now after all this time? So this is sex. Men and women coupling. This is why they were thrown out of Paradise. (watches the snakes) But everything is of God. And everything has two negpings, one obvious, one hidden. What are they telling me? He looks at one of the snakes. It speaks to him in Mary Magdalene's voice: : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SNAKE/MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Jesus, I forgive you. The snakes change color as they coil. Is this real -- ora vision? The question doesn't occur to Jesus. Nor would it to his contemporaries. They lived in a time which accepte healings, miracles, stigmata and visions as extensions of the natural world. Jesus grabs his chest; the snakes hiss inside his breast.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Leave me alone. Jesus breathes a sigh of relief. The Abbot stands in the door, Jesus looks up. The snakes are gone.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Jesus doesn't answer, The Abbot puts his fingers to Jesus lips.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: They're gone.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Yes, they've fled.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: And now you must leave too.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: The snakes came from you. Now you must leave too. Go into the villages. Stand and speak.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: To anyone who will listen.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: And say what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that. Just open your mouth. Do you love mankind?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I see men and I feel sorry for them, nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: That's enough. It’s time for you to leave, .

dialogues.speaker: , JESUS
dialogues.text: That's why I was sent here?

dialogues.speaker: ABBOT
dialogues.text: I don *t know. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon illuminates the walled enclave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A palm-sized lamp burns as Jesus straightens his room. Hi few possessions are neatly laid out for travel. He hears a HISSING NOISE outside the room. Stops. Listens He cautiously opens the door and steps into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus strains to see:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Hello? Suddenly an arm grabs Jesus from behind and throws him against the wall. Judas stands in front of him, panting, his double-edged dagger in his hand. His red face glistens with anger.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Crucifier! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Judas? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Welcome. I've come to kill you. I hissed and you came. Judas pushes Jesus inside the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judas locks the door behind him. He throws the ‘elbow key across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? Don't start crying. Get ready. Jesus, composed, stands across the room.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I am ready.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Don't make any noise. Don't call for help.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I'm happy to see you, Judas, It wasn't you that hissed, It was God, Can't you see? This is perfect, Tonight, I was cleansed. I'm tired of wrestling with God; I'm tired of living. (opens his tunic) Here's my neck. Cut it with your knife. Judas backs off. He is disgusted by the sight of Jesus’ bare neck, He has come here to fig t like a man, To spill blood in a struggle. He puts his dagger to Jesus’ neck:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Why don't you resist? What kind of man are you? Fight!

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (calm) Why? What you want, I want -- and God must want it too, because that's why he brought us together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . JUDAS
dialogues.text: (takes his knife down) I put a knife to your neck and you don't blink. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Think whatever you want,

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (studies him a second) ~ Okay. You may think I'm just a stupid blacksmith. But you talk -- I'll understand. Who are you? What do you want? What are all these stories which follow you; a flowering staff, a Lightning flash, the voices you hear, the fainting spells which seize you? What's your secret?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Pity.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Pity for who? Yourself? For Israel? Is that it? Are you tortured by Israel's suffering?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Pity for man.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Man! The Greeks who slaughtered us -- they were men, weren't they? And the Romans -- they're men, too. Don't pity man, pity Israel. The rest can go to Hell.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I feel pity for donkeys, sparrows...

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: And ants? I suppose you feel pity for them, too?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Yes. Everything's a part of God. When I look into the ant, into his shiny black eye, I see God. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: You don't fear death?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Why should I? Death isn't a door which closes; it's a door which opens. It opens and you enter. Judas, confused, lowers his knife:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: If I don't kill you, what will you do?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I don't know. LI want to speak to others,

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: What are you going to say?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I'll just open my mouth and God will do the talking. Judas wavers between confusion and anger. He looks at Jes he sees a GLOW behind his head. He no longer has any tast for this task.

dialogues.speaker: . JESUS
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for Judas?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Who are you? Maybe you're the one who will make the people rise up against the Romans. Maybe you're the one we've been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Maybe God didn't send you to kill me. Maybe he sent you here to follow me. I am ready to be killed: I'm also ready to live. Decide. Judas is in a quandry:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Don't be in such a rush. It's a long night. (pause) You're a strange one, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I’m going to do. I'm going to sleep down here by the door and think about it, You turn your head away from me. I need more time to think, Jesus lies on his mat, his face to the wall. Judas sits, his back to the door, thinking. He puts his knife away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, GALILEE
dialogues.text: Judas and Jesus walk across the plain toward Magdala. A wind blows across the Sea of Gennesaret. On the hillside, the flowers -- red anemones and white narcissus -- are in bloom. . Jesus, bearded, is dressed in monastery whites. For the first time he looks like familiar Jesus of romantic paint ings. The meager possessions are wrapped in cloth. Judas and Jesus appear to home come to an understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zebedee, James, John, Philip and two others approach the house. Two camels, their hampers packed, are tied outside The buildings are constructed of wood and black basalt ro

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: (points to camel) Can you believe this? It's bad enough we live in a whorehouse, but she, a Jew, works on Sabbath, While our women can't even look in a mirror, she makes ‘love' with Romans. Zebedee's voice is raised. A crowd starts to gather. TABA a Zealot and trouble-maher, joins with two companions.

dialogues.speaker: TABAS
dialogues.text: Yeah, we come back from synagogue and and lock the other way. A WOMAN stands across the narrow street:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN OF MAGDALA
dialogues.text: You ought to see the things I see. I'm too poor to move, so I have to put up with it.  24 25 23.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: You shouldn't move.

dialogues.speaker: TABAS
dialogues.text: The whore should move.

dialogues.speaker: TABAS' COMPANION
dialogues.text: Let's put an end to it. Tabas and his companions bang on Magdalene's door. The growing crowds egg them on. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and Judas enter the village. The streets are quiet. It is Sabbath. Ahead, they hear a commotion.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Let's find out. They hurry through the streets until they come to a clear A mob has assembled around a shallow pit. Judas, the man of action, pushes his way through the crow Jesus .follows. Mary Magdalene lies in the pit, her knees and elbows are bloody from being dragged down the street. Terrified. The crowd, in a festive mood, hurl insults and spit at he Children collect rocks for a stoning.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (to Judas; urgent) It's Magdalene. Jesus steps into the center of the pit, stands next to Magdalene and holds up his hands:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Stop! First there's a stunned silence, then a buzz runs through the crowd. No one is more surprised than Judas. He watche closely. In the crowd Philip and Peter have joined Andrew and John Tabas calls out: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TABAS
dialogues.text: Get out of the way. She violated the Sabbath. She must pay the price. A small anonymous stone hits Magdalene's hip. She grabs Jesus' leg.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Help!

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: (chants) Death! Death! Death! Jesus walks in a circle around Magdalene. He stares her accusors in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Listen to me! Look me in the face. Which of you has not stolen, lied, murdered? Let the one without sin throw the first stone. The crowd is frozen, Zebedee picks up a large rock.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. I'm innocent.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (steps up to him) Don't make a mistake, Zebedee. There is a God. Don't tell me you've never cheated an employee, snuck into a widow's bedroom at night? Aren't you afraid God will paralyze you if you lift that stone? at your hand will wither and hang at your side? . The old man is suddenly filled with fear and superstition Zebedee drops the rock and runs. The sympathies of the mo shift to Jesus. Judas is heartened. Perhaps this is the leader to unite the people. Tabas and his companions start toward Jesus, but Judas st between them, braced for action. The crowd, afraid of Jud backs away. Jesus helps Mary to her feet. Judas calls to the crowd: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS 12 .
dialogues.text: Come, follow the rabbi.“ He will speak, Judas, Jesus and Magdalene walk away from the pit toward outskirts of town. A large segment of the crowd follows. One VILLAGER whispers to another:

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER
dialogues.text: What's happening? Is Magdalene getting married? cut To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and Judas lead the curious crowd up a steep, green hillside. In the distance the sun is low over Mt. Hebron. Magdalene sits near Jesus' feet; Judas stands in the back ground. The crowd waits to hear what Jesus has to say. Jesus looks out over the racamuffin villagers, the peacef countryside:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the moment I've always feared. There is so much to say. God has so many miracles. A pause. The words burst out:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Brothers! I'm glad to see you. Let me tell you a story. A man, a sower, was sowing in his field. One seed fell on the road -- the brids ate it. Another fell on stones and died. But another took root, sprouted, became grain and fed many people. (pause) Don't you have ears? Do you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: (beligerent) I got ears, but I don't understand. Be clearer. Jesus thinks, then says softly:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I am the sower. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: God help us! I suppose we're the stones? A moment of confusion. Zebedee says to those near him:

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: Another beggar. John, an open-faced, fuzzy-cheeked boy about 19, leaves h father and approaches Jesus:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Rabbi, tell me. If you are the sower and we are the stones, what is the seed? Jesus is baffled; he has no answer. John repeats the question:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: What is the seed you offer? The answer comes to Jesus:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Love one another. Love one another! The crowd whispers: "What did he say?" "Love each other?"

dialogues.speaker: TABAS
dialogues.text: That's stupid. We're starving. Tortured. Hungry. How can hungry people love each other?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (steps forward) Yes, 'Rabbi,' is this what I've been waiting for? Love one another? T suppose that means love the Romans too

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I used to think God was angry, but not any more. He used to jump on my head like a crazy bird with claws. But then he came to me like 2 cool breeze and said, ‘arise’ -- and here I am.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: Go to hell! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TABAS
dialogues.text: Pie in the sky. Jesus, speaking rapidly, goes directly to the social conc of the mob:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst after righteousness, for their stomachs will be filled with bread. Blessed are those who mourn, for God will comfort them. Blessed are the meek, the suffering, for God will give them a kingdom in heaven. Jesus is now talking like a prophet -- a Zealot. The dirt-poor villagers are agitated: "Yes, we will get t wealth of the rich; we'll get Israel back."

dialogues.speaker: FIRST VOICE
dialogues.text: Let's kill the rich!

dialogues.speaker: . SECOND VOICE
dialogues.text: Why bother with the rich? Kill the Romans!

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (protests) I didn't say death. I said love! The crowd, incited by rhetoric and hunger, disperses in search of shops to plunder.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: (motions to his son) Come on, let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No. Go on without me. John and Andrew stay behind with Peter, Philip and Judas. Jesus wipes Mary Magdalene's bloody feet with his tunic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: Rabbi. I'll come with you. You need someone to cook and...

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No. Go back home and be an example. He helps her to her feet, kisses her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. Jesus leads his little band along the seasho Peter, John and Andrew walk with Jesus; Judas and Philip follow. Two peasant women, a street urchin and a couple o doszs bring up the rear. They approach Zebedee who mends his nets with James, Nathaniel and two other fishermen.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: Hello Zebedee.

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: (to John) Where have you been? We've been working all morning. John steps over to his brother:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come with us. Believe me -- this is for real. Just what we talked about.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: (joining in) You don't have to work for your old man anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: But I told Nathaniel I would go to his cousin's wedding...

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: {to Zebedee) Watch out you'll lose another son.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (to James) Put down your net. I'11 make you a fisher of men. James does not respond. Jesus leads his group down the shore. As they go, Zebedee calls to John:

dialogues.speaker: ZEBEDEE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (laughing) To the Kindgom of God! James watches as they recede. He thinks a moment, drops h net and runs to. follow them. cut TO:  28 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The disciples sleep in an olive grove. Jesus, awake, sits a nearby knoll, looking into the night. Judas walks over and sits next to him:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Rabbi. I'd like to talk. (sits) I don't feel comfortable with the others. I mean, they're good men, but weak. They couldn't defend themselves, much less fight for you. I'm a rough man -- hard but honest. Who I love, I die for; who I hate, I kill. (Jesus doesn't answer) I can even kill someone I love if he does the wrong thing. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: The other day when you said turn the other cheek to the man that hit you, I didn't like that. I'ma free man, not a slave. I don't turn my cheek to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I want freedom, too.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: You do? You want freedom for Israel?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I want freedom for the soul.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Un-ah. There's no freedom for the soul without freedom for the body. You know that. The Romans come ‘irst.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: The soul is first. Andrew, sleepy-eyed, walks over, concerned:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Who's there? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It’s me, Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep. Judas and I are having a private talk. Andrew turns and leaves. Judas waits until he is out of earshot:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the Zealots commissioned me to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Why did you stop?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: I decided to wait.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: To see if you were the one we're waiting for. I don't want to kill Israel's Savior -- not me. I said, ‘Wait, he may not even know it yet.’ But don't listen to the others -- they're sheep. It's you and I who will decide who's burning you up -- God or Satan, If you waver from Israel's path, I!11 kill you. Don't be fooled.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: How can we know? I was full of hate when I saw them torturing Magdalene. Yet I opened my mouth and out came the word 'lov2'. Help me. What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (thinks } We'll go to Judea and see John the Baptist. He stands out every day shouting, 'He is coming, He is coming.' Let him decide.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (nods) Okay. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a beat) I'm afraid, Judas. Stay here. Judas spreads his blanket on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. Judas is asleep. Jesus awakens. Jesus surveys the still black night. He pulls an apple from his tunic, picks a seed from it and tosses it to the ground. A tree grows immediately from the seed. Ripe, red apples grow from every branch. - cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and his disciples approach Cana, a village west of Magdala and Gennesaret. His “merry band" has swelled to a dozen or so, women and children included, A celebration is going on in town: Nathaniel's cousin is getting married. Jesus and his followers are all in good spirits: it's a festive occasion. Village children run away, announcing Jesus’ arrival. He's become a local celebrity in the past several weeks. Nathaniel greets James on the outskirts of town:

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: Hello, James. You've come for my cousin's wedding?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: If we're welcome. Nathaniel, this is Jesus from Nazareth, our Rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: Yes, we've heard about you. Will you bless the couple? (Jesus nods) There's gonna be a big party tonight. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-dozen virgins, freshly-bathed, carrying lit lamps, sing a wedding psalm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jesus exchanges small talk with a group waiting for the ceremony to begin. Mary Magdalene steps next to Jesus. She looks like a chan woman: simply dressed, radiant.

dialogues.speaker: MAGDALENE
dialogues.text: I heard you were here. Jesus takes her hand. An OLD MAN says to Mary:

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: You don’t belong at a wedding. We're here to celebrate purity.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I'Ll tell you a story. There were ten virgins waiting for the groom. Five filled their lamp; five didn't. The groom was late and the five foolish virgins went to get more oil. He let the wise virgins in and locked the door, When the foolish virgins came they begged to get in. What would you have done? The Old Man doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (to Nathaniel) What would you have done?

dialogues.speaker: NATHANTEL
dialogues.text: (thinks) I guess I woulda let them in.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: You're right. That's what the groom did. He said, 'This is a feast. Let everyone eat and drink.' (points to Mary) God's kingdom is large enough for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Nazarene, that's against the law.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: The Law is against my heart.  me ry rn, “~~ 32 n

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The ceremony is over. Jesus, the disciples and the other guests are laughing, drinking and swapping stories. (Jesu hand rests on Magdalene's shoulder.) The wine has loosene everyone's spirits. Everyone but Nathaniel: he's upset.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: . NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: I didn't buy enough wine. More people came and stayed late and now we're out. Jesus points to several large vats:

dialogues.speaker: . JESUS
dialogues.text: What's in those?

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: Water.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No. It's wine.

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: Com'on.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Go over, Check it out. It's wine. Nathaniel goes over to a vat, lifts the lid, dips his finger inside and tastes:

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: You're right. It is wine.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (as a joke) It's a miracle. Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and his followers rearch the edge of the Dead Sea. Sixty miles south of Galilee, it seems like another count The green hills of Gennesaret have been replaced by barre plains and rocky cliffs. In the background the mountains of Moab are pink against the midday sun. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee eee

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jesus takes Andrew by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (with trepidation) Where is he? Where's the Baptist?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Ahead, beyond the reeds the river is calm. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: You're tired. Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It my be dangerous. I'd better come.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No. I want to go alone. Jesus walks through the burning heat toward the oasis. Judas, who had been following behind, runs and catches up to him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: You forgot to call me, This is the big moment. I want to be with you,

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Come along. They walk down a slope. John the Baptist's voice echoes i the distance, They push their way through a mixture of lo class Israelites, Jesus gasps when he first sees THE BAPTIST: a wild man, unkempt, unwashed, dressed in animal skins, he shouts in wind:

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: Repent! The day of the Lord has come! Roll on the crowd, bite the dust, howl! The Lord says: ‘On this day I shall command the sun to set at noon; I shall crush the horns of the new moon and spill darkness over earth. I shall reverse your laughter, turn it into tears, and your songs into lamentations. I shall blow and all your finery -~ hands, feet, noses, ears, hairs -- will fall to the ground.’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Iw

dialogues.speaker: LA
dialogues.text: h t

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's awesome. Even Judas is taken back. He grabs Jesus:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Master, can't you hear? It's the Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: , JESUS
dialogues.text: No, the Messiah won't come with an ax in his hand. Jesus walks ahead; Judas calls to him:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: We'll see. Go to him! Jesus walks slowly toward the Baptist, his eyes fixed on prophet. The crowd flails and shouts in the manner of mod day Pentacostalists.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Even from behind, I knew I had seen him before. Where? When? Was it a dream? Yes, it was. But he was all dressed in white. Jesus steps behind the Baptist. John suddenly turns at hi

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: Who are you? Who?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (his voice trembling) De you recognize me?

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Have you read Isaiah, forerunner? Do you know the prophets?

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: You're The Chosen One?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I don't know. (demanding) Tell me. The Baptist locks around: the crowd wails in SILENT MOTIO A sudden calmmess. He starts to shake:

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: Why have you come? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: To be baptized.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: I don't dare. If you are the Master, you should baptize me.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. Do your duty. Baptize me. Jesus kneels at John's feet. Judas looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and the Baptist sit on the dark river bank. A group of pilgrims camp in the distance. They are weary from hours of debate:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Isn't love enough?

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: No. The tree is rotten. You must take the ax and cut it down.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: If I was a woodcutter, I'd cut; if I was a fire, I'd bum. But I'ma heart and I love.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: (with evangelical fervor) What do the prophecies say? ‘On the day of t ord, blood will flow from wood, the stones of the houses will come alive and kill their owners!' The day of the Lord is here. I was given the ax, now I pass it to you. Jesus, frightened, stands and turns away:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No, I cannot. Be patient. I'll go to the desert. To Idumaea. God will speak to me there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST .
dialogues.text: Watch out. God isn't alone out there. Devils are waiting too -- I know. The Baptist walks over to Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Baptist. John kisses Jesus on the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His tongue felt like a burning coal in my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAPTIST
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid. You are the One. Two roads open up in front of you: the road of man, the road of God. Take the more difficult one. Make your arms strong. Strike! Jesus walks away, not looking back. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus runs across the desert as if pursued, He stops, pants, continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day. Jesus wanders through the wild, uninhabited terrain. The sun, like a blast furnace, blows sand into h ace, He sits beside a large rock:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'm not going any further. This is it: I'm staying here. I'm a grain of sand in this desert, God. Can you see me? I have no weapon but love. (draws a.circle in the sand) I'm not going to leave this circle, I won't leave until you talk to me. And not with hums, or thunder or headaches -- but with a clear human voice. Tell me which path to take. Or else let me die here. FADE OUT.  37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN. Days have past, The hunger and deprivation are beginning to show on Jesus' face. His clothes are the col or soil. He hears a sound, looks into the moonlit night: a large SERPENT coils at the edge of the circle. The Serpent speaks in a half-human, half-animal voice.

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: I felt sorry for you, Jesus. You were lonely. You cried, "I don't want to be alone,' so I came.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I didn't call you. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: Your soul.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: My soul!

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: You're afraid of being alone. Just like Adam. He called me and I reached into his ribs and gave him a wife.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: You want me to do wrong.

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: Do wrong? To love and care for a woman? To have a family -- this is wrong? Why are you trying to save the world? The world' doesn't want to be saved, Find love,

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I have love.

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: Look into my eyes, look at my breasts... The Serpent's voice dissolves into the soft, comforting voice of Mary Magdalene.

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: ..- Do you recognize them? Say the word. Nod your head and we'll be in my bed together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: SERPENT
dialogues.text: (compassionately) Oh, Jésus. The Serpent suddenly explodes, leaving no trace. Jesus pl his head between his legs and begins te sob, as if he has lost a loved one. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN. Another week has passed. Jesus' clothes are torn and tattered by the desert winds. He awakens.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After ten days the hunger went away. He hears a sound. A LION stands at the edge of the circle

dialogues.speaker: LION
dialogues.text: Welcome, Jesus. Congratulations. You've overcome the petty temptations of a woman, a family. We're both bigger than that. A woman's not enough, we need the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: LION
dialogues.text: I am you. I am your heart, your hungry heart which pretends to be humble but wants to conquer the world. I will set my four feet down, one in Babylon, one in Jerusalem, one in Alexandria, the last in Rome.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I've never wanted a kingdom on earth. Heaven's good enough for me. The Lion's voice transforms into Judas':

dialogues.speaker: LION
dialogues.text: You lie. You've always wanted power. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LION, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you were making crosses for the Romans in Nazareth, your head was exploding with dreams of power. You said it was God, but you really wanted to rule others. Now you will. Jesus, shaking, approaches the Lion.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Step into my circle, liar, so I can pull out your tongue. The Lion steps into the circle, and, as he does, disappea / FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN. Jesus lies sleeping by the rock. Another week ha past. He's a wasted skeleton. A blinding, hallucinatory light wakes him. An ARCHANGEL s at the circle's edge. e Angle is a ten-year-old boy, dres in white with soft wings folded under his arms. Jesus strains to see through his swollen eyelids:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHANGEL
dialogues.text: I'm the one you've been waiting for. Remember when you were a child, you eried, ‘Make me a God. God, make me a God.'

dialogues.speaker: , JESUS
dialogues.text: But I was just a child then.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHANGEL
dialogues.text: Adonai. You are God. The Baptist told you. Join me in power. We will rule over the living and the dead. You will sit on the throne, I'll sit at your right hand. Jesus suddenly realizes who he's talking to:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Satan! The ripe tree from Jesus' dream appears behind the Archan The Angel offers Jesus an apple. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jesus bites ito the apple: it turns into bleod in his mou The blood drips down his chest. The Archangel's soft feathe wings grow into black, spiked flanges, tising menacingly above his shoulder blades. The tree withers behind him. The boy smiles:

dialogues.speaker: ANGEL
dialogues.text: We will meet again. The Archangel turns and leaves. Jesus picks up a stick at his feet. The stick is an ax. The Baptist's voice speaks to him:

dialogues.speaker: BAPTIST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The day of the Lord is here. Run and carry the message: ‘I am coming.' Jesus strikes at the root of the treet with the ax. The s turns red: there is a deafening thunderbolt followed by a lightning flash. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. An emaciated figure in tattered clothes etands silhouetted in the doorway. MARY and MARTHA, sisters in their early thirties, tum aghast. Mary sits at a waving loom; Martha near the fire.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: er.. From Galilee. I'ma foreign I'n hungry and need rest. cold an

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Martha) Lazarus is out. We're alone. (to Jesus) Are you a good man?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (to Jesus) Don't let my sister's fears worry you. I'm Martha, this is Mary. We don’t have much, but you're welcome to what we have. Who are you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Jesus of Nazareth. He staggers into the room, collapses on the hearth. cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night falls on their modest Bethany home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, washed and wearing a new tunic, eats bread and oli Martha hands him wine flask. Sitting by the fire, they almost look like a family wit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Speak more. We don't know anything about you.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What is there to say?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Silence doesn't satisfy a woman. Women need a kind word.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Don't listen to her. Not even silence is enough for a woman. She wants a husband in bed at night. She wants a baby to suck her breasts -- but what do men know?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you have a wife?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (thinks) No. They lapse into silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: These are hard times. The King has killed the Baptist. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It was at Herod's palace in Tiberius. The King was drunk. They say he had the prophet beheaded to satisfy a girl. Jesus smashes his forehead against that fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Oh, God. These are the final days.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (unable to hear him) What?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (stands) I must go.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: But you've hardly had time to rest.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please stay.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: It's time to leave. He stops at the door, smiles compassionately at them:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mary, Martha. God will bless you for your kindness. (a sad beat) I wish I could stay. He closes the door behind him. “Martha looks at Mary, dow cast. A good man had entered taeir lives, like a miracle. Now he is gone. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torches light the exterior of a small inn near the Sheeps Gate. (So named because the sheep were sold here.) 15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The disciples sit around several tables. The INN-KEEPER sleeps on a bed of straw.in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Now they say they're going to kill everyone who was baptized.

dialogues.speaker: _ PHILIP
dialogues.text: Nobody told you to get baptized. Serves you right.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You were baptized, too. Begged for it. So, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I hear the fishing is great in Gennasaret. You just drop the nets in and they fill with fish.

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know what's happened to my sheep.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So go back,

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We promised the Master we'd wait here for him.

dialogues.speaker: NATHANIEL
dialogues.text: It's been over a month. He talks to The Baptist, then disappears.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIP
dialogues.text: How do we know what The Baptist said?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Talk like that will get you a swelled head -- just like the Baptist. They all laugh. Judas interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: I say we wait. A momentary silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I agree with Judas -- and say we have another drink. (calls out) Inn-keeper, wake up! We need more wine. The Inn-keeper sleepily obliges. The door opens: Jesus enters. Jesus heart. John sinks to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Master.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Thanks for waiting, my dear friends. It-hasn't been a waste of time. JOHN © What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Were you baptized?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes. :

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: John baptized with water and they killed him. Now I will baptize with fire.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Is this the message of the Baptist? reaches into his chest and pulls out his own bloody He offers it at arms length to the disciples. Blood drips from the ventricles.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: This is my heart. Please take it. I lead the way. If you have sheep, give them away; if you have nets, et them rot; family, children, leave them behind. We're on the march. Jesus places his heart back in his chest.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I once believed in love, now I carry the ax. Are you with me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Judas falls to his knees and kisses Jesus’ feet:

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Adonail The others follow Judas' example.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You lead, we'll follow.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: We're going back to Nazareth. We'll begin our campaign there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and his followers (they have grown in number) walk through the Samarian lowlands. Mts. Gerigim and Ebal lie to the east. 1 . The group advances with determination and purpose. Judas at Jesus’ right; Peter at his left. A cluster of indigent villagers, women and children follow them. They come upon a makeshift asylum for the insane. The men are housed in a group of low-lying buildings. The deranged men run toward Jesus, fall at his feet, beg pitiful jibberish. . Judas and Peter try to ward them off. Jesus is angry -- not at the men, but at the evil spirits that possess them He slaps one man, kicks another:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Satan! Leave these men alone. Get out! (points) Go into those pigs over there. The insane men grow suddenly calm. The disciples turn to watch as the herd of swine, squealing, run cff a cliff an plunge into the ravine. The insane have returmed to their senses. Most are con- fused, some praise Jesus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Go to the temple and cleanse yourselves. That said, Jesus moves on, He doesn't give a second thoug to the "miracle" he has performed. LATER. A BLINDMAN, led by his BROTHER and SISTER, approac Jesus and the disciples. His reputation has spread throug the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: Mister, welcome. Come to our home.

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: Adonai.

dialogues.speaker: SISTER
dialogues.text: My brother has no sight.

dialogues.speaker: BLIND MAN
dialogues.text: Adonai, help me. Jesus stops. He takes ground herbal powder from his sleev and mixes it with sand. He spits into the mixture, then applies st to the Blind Man's eyes. He looks upwards and chants:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Jeremiah, Moses, Elijah, Isaizh -- touch my mouth, touch my lips. Jesus kisses the man's mud-caked eves. The clay falls fro the Blind Man's eyes. His gruesomely deformed eyes are no normal: he can see.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Go to the temple, Tell no one what has happened. Jesus motions for his disciples to follow. They continue talking among themselves. The Blind Man stands behind, stunned. His Sister embraces him. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NAZARETH
dialogues.text: Sabbath. The faithful, fresh from synagogue, mill about under the date palms in the manner of churchmen over the centuries. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: These are not common people. On the contrary, they repres the Jewish hierarchy: the severely moral Pharisees, with their belief in afterlife; their rivals, the legalistic Saducees, in collusion with the Romans; and landowners and shopkeepers who supported the synagogue. There is a commotion. Several of the churchmen point in t direction of Jesus and his band of rabble. Jesus mounts t rocky crucifixion site. He calls out:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Brothers! Listen to me. Isaiah eried, ‘The spirit of the Lord flowed over me, he chose me to bring good news to the poor, he sent me to set free the slaves and make the blind see." The churchmen, curious, gather around.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (continuing) My dear old friends: The prophet was talking about me. God came to me in the desert. He gave me a great secret and told me to bring it to you -- didn't you hear me coming? I ran here first -~- to give the news to my hometown, The kingdom of the Lord has come! Someone from the crowd taunts him:

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER
dialogues.text: We hear you do miracles. Do one for us.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (impassioned) Everything is a miracle. Look at the sky, Fook at the weeds under your feet. The Day of the Lord is here. ‘there are only a few hours left. Are you ready? Call the poor and give them your goods before it is too late. What you care about your possessions? Your gold and silver will rust and their rust will eat your flesh like fire. You will drown in the sweat of the poor. Look above your heads. The flames of God are already coming down! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The local burghers boo and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER
dialogues.text: Who are you, the son of Mary, to tell us about God?

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER
dialogues.text: I remember when he made crosses. (to companion) Get his brothers to take him away.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What are you laughing at? Are you trying to protect your houses and olive trees -- they will all tum to ashes. Ashes! th wh VILLAGER #2 is is what happens when doesn't marry. The semen backs up into his brain. Someone throws a stone; it grazes Jesus’ head, drawing bl

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGER
dialogues.text: Go home! You're full of devils.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (wiping blood from his brow) This is my home! Peter and Judas rush to Jesus' defense. Judas puts his ha to his dagger.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Shame on you! What has he done to you? The soil-colored poor from the slums have begun to gather around. These are the "Am Ha-aretz," the destitute Lower classes oppressed by wealthy Jews and Romans alike. They think: Jesus is right. This is the new law. The kingdom of the poor has come. The rich and poor scuffle, exchanging insults and taunts. The scene is near chaos when JESUS' BROTHER arrives with friends. They struggle to take Jesus down hill.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS' BROTHER
dialogues.text: Jesus, come with us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: James, you're my brother. Leave me alone. Judas draws his dagger. Jesus breaks free of his brother.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (te Judas) Put it away. This is ne town for prophets. We'll go to Jerusalem (to Thomas) Blow your horn, we're leaving. Thomas blows his trumpet as Jesus walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and his followers head across the plain toward Sama

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: If I could touch every stone, breathe on every twig, they would rise up and join me. Jerusalem is falling. I can feel it. He turns to Judas who walks at his side: .

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: We're going to Jerusalem.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Not the Old Jerusalem, the New Jerusalen.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: A New Jerusalem!

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Yes, we will build it. See this silly group of fools, cripples, jealous, blind, petty -- this is our army. They will shout and the Old Jerusalem will fall. God can endure it no longer.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (looks back) This isn't much of an army. Remember the Maccabees. We'll need more men. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: God will provide. Judas and Jesus walk in step. John rus alongside the Mast

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Master, your mother is here.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Your mother , Mary, possessed by maternal frenzy, grabs Jesus’ arm:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (MOTHER OF JESUS)
dialogues.text: Son, please come home. I'1l take care of you. You're sick but I'll make you better. (to others) Forgive him. Help me take him home.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Who are you, woman?

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (MOTHER OF JESUS)
dialogues.text: (desperate) Your mother.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I have no mother, no brothers. Only my father who is in heaven. Get away from me. He shakes his arm from her grip. Mary falls to her knees erying. Jesus keeps walking. The disciples follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and his ragtag "army" continue their southward marc Judas looks with pride at their growing numbers. Martha and Mary, dressed in black, approach Jesus. He wal . over to then.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA /
dialogues.text: Rabbi, forgive us. We heard you were near. We've walked two days. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Our brother Lazarus is very sick. We heard you've performed miracles, healed the sick, made eripples walk, blind...

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Take me to him. CuT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jesus, Martha, Mary and the others approach Bethany, a village WOMAN runs to meet then.

dialogues.speaker: BETHANY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Mary, Martha, you've come too late. Lazarus is dead. He was buried three days ago. Martha falls into Jesus' arms; He consoles her.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Take me to the tomb. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus and a select group of disciples approach a row of tombs carved into the hillside. The Bethany Woman points out Lazarus’ tomb. It is sealed by a large boulder. Jesus instructs Judas and Peter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll away the stone. They elicit the help of two others and lean their shoulde to the difficult task.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What am I going to do? The stone moves: a hideous stench gusts from the tomb. Some disciples turn their faces; others put handkerchiefs to their noses. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jesus stands at the entrance of the tomb and yells, His voice echoes: a wild, strange cry, like something from another world.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Lazarus! In the name of the prophets, in the name of Jeremiah and my Father, the most Holy God, I demand that you rise and come out! At first, nothing. Then, slowly, a dessicated figure emer from the tomb, He is wrapped head to toe in white burial cloth. The crowd gasps, Slowly, and with great effort, LAZARUS unwraps the soiled linen from his face. Jesus is frightenéd by his own mirac

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is the power of God so great? If it can raise the dead, can it also move mountains? Can it destroy ‘Rome? Tear the world in two? Strips of rotting flesh drip off Lazarus' face, The disci step back, astounded. Lazarus smiles at Jesus:

dialogues.speaker: LAZARUS
dialogues.text: Adonail Jesus embraces hin,

dialogues.speaker: JESUS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: God help me.

dialogues.speaker: INT, MARY AND MARTHA'S
dialogues.text: Mary, Martha and family friends minister to the feeble La He seems confused, not quite sure if he is dead or alive. Jesus passes them and walks outside, cUuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, MARY AND MARTHA'S
dialogues.text: Judas, Peter and John are sitting at a table in the garde Jesus joins them, interrupting their small talk.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Peter, Judas tell me, who do people think I am?20 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: You know -- what do they say?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Some say you're John the Baptist, reborn.. :

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That's stupid. Some say you're Ezekial, others, Jeremiah. Jesus sits down.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Who do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: My favorite character is David. My mother always used to talk about him. When he conquered Jerusalum he put the Jebusites to the ban -- killed all of the, didn't fool around. Gave everybody to God. The same with the Ammonites,

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I always liked Ezekial.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Ezekial!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah. He didn't mince words about anything. Remember Obolibah -- the Jerusalem women who made love to the Chaldeans 'cause they were hung? (gestures; laughs) Ezekial wasn't afraid of anybody. He just told the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: My favorite is Isaiah...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Sex, that's all it was...

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: (interrupts; to Jesus) Who do you like? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Jeremiah.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Jeremiah was a loser...

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: You should have had his guts. He was born right near here, you know. Just over the hill. He said, the ~ Lord would write a New Covenant. I'll make it with Israel. I'll put my law in their minds. I'll write it in their hearts.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Isaiah knew right from wrong. How long ago did he live?

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: I don't know. Before Jeremiah,

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No, Jeremiah was before Ezekial.

dialogues.speaker: JUDAS
dialogues.text: Get off ic. (to Peter) When was Jeremiah?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Beats me.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (thinks) I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prior to the Passover feast, from the 15th to the 25tt of Adar, every Jewish male had to pay a temple tax in the amount of one Galilean shekel. Since the coin of the land was Roman (and to a lesser extent Persian, Tyrian and Syr money-changers were needed to exchange Roman denarii for shekels. Obviously, they made a profit on this exchange. The money-changers had permanent booths outside the templ Proper. To a stranger the temple looked more like a broke house than a place of worship. Jesus enters the temple grounds with his central core of disciples. They have come to worship. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jesus comes to a cold stop: he's sickened by the sight of the money-changers. He tums to Peter:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's for the feast. Jesus, enraged, strides past the booths, overturning the tables. Scales, weights and coins from all over the world Scatter in every direction. The vendors rush to retrieve their money. Other vendors and customers turn on Jesus. Judas, Peter a the others forcibly fight them off. Jesus calls out:

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: My father's house is a place of worship, not a bank, or a store. The disciples circle Jesus for his protection. The RABBI, surroumded by SADDUCEES, steps out of the temple.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Nazarene, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: God doesn't need a fancy house. He doesn't need cyprus and bloody animals. For years I used to come to the temple, but now the temple has come to me.

dialogues.speaker: SADDUCEE
dialogues.text: (shocked) Watch what you say.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: When I say, 'I,' Rabbi, I am saying ‘God.'

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: This is blasphemy!

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear? I'm the Saint of Blasphemy. Make no mistake: 1 haven't come to bring peace, I've come to bring a sword. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Sadduccee whispers to an associate, then Says to Jesu

dialogues.speaker: SADDUCCEE
dialogues.text: Take your ideas to the Romans.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I'm sick of all of you. This temple will be destroyed. “One stone won't stand on another. God does not belong in a ghetto. God is not an Israelitel Even the disciples are shocked by this heresy. They escor Jesus out of the temple grounds for his ow safety. As they reach the temple gates they are mobbed by the poo and the infirm waiting outside. The beggars press on Jesu pulling at his arms an legs.

dialogues.speaker: MOB MEMBER
dialogues.text: Heal me.

dialogues.speaker: MOB MEMBER
dialogues.text: Cure us. Make us rich.

dialogues.speaker: MOB MEMBER
dialogues.text: Do a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: (pushes them away) Get away. You sicken me. You're selfish and full of hate. God won't help you. This new crisis is broken up by four Roman cavalrymen. Th stampede into the mob, whipping beggars and curiosity-see alike. The OFFICER demands:

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Who is Jesus from Nazareth?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I an.

dialogues.speaker: ROMAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: Come with us. The Procurator wants to see you. The calvarymen lead Jesus away, leaving the disciples behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Roman garrison, the Antonia fort, was situated on the northwest wall of the temple. Roman soldiers, standing on the Antonia walls, could observe all the activities in th temple grounds. The Roman soldiers escort Jesus into an open courtyard. PILATE, 22 dressed in leather and metal military regalia, waits for him on a raised platform decorated by crudely carved eagles. Two soldiers, spears in hand, flank the Procurator. -

dialogues.speaker: PILATE
dialogues.text: Are you Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews?

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: I'm not a king.

dialogues.speaker: PILATE
